description: Beginning on March 22, Gabon is implementing a country-wide curfew from 7:30pm to 6:00am.

On April 27, the Gabonese government announced that the state of extended curfew for 15 days through to May 11. Restriction measures introduced under the state of emergency remain in place including a nationwide curfew from 19:30 to 06:00 (local time) especially in Libreville and the nearby communities of Owendo, Akanda, Ntoum, and Pointe Denis.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Beginning on March 22, Gabon is implementing a country-wide curfew from 7:30pm to 6:00am. Starting April 27, the curfew will last from 6pm to 6am. UPDATE: On April 27, Gabon orders a national curfew from 6pm to 6am.
On April 28, the Government of Gabon announced a Traffic ban between 6 p.m. and 6 a.m. throughout the whole of the national territory until next order.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 28, the Gabonese government eased measures in the Grand Libreville area, including the communes of Libreville, Owendo, Akanda, Ntoum, and the Pointe-Denis peninsula. The new measures replaced a total lockdown with a curfew between the hours of 17:00 and 07:00. Residents of Grand Libreville are to remain isolated from the rest of Gabon, with fines enforceable for violation of restrictions until next order.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 29, the Gabonese government announced in the capital, Libreville. Travelling within greater Libreville is now permitted between 6:00 am and 6:00 pm whilst the rest of Gabon is under travel ban.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 11, the Gabonese Government extended the national curfew. Gabon's state of emergency imposed amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic expires at midnight (local time) on May 11, but the government has confirmed Restrictions on movement, a nationwide curfew from 19:30 to 06:00
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 18, the Gabonese Government extended the national curfew. All parts of the country are subject to a curfew between 6:00 pm and 6:00 am.

description: On October 26 the Gabonese government announced that people holding a Laissez-Passer (a pass issued to people carrying out essential services during curfew hours) will have to renew this via a new internet platform laissezpassercovid19@gouv.ga. Failure to comply with the measures would constitute a criminal offence and can lead to fines or community service."

description: On April 10, Gabonese president Ali Bongo declares a state of emergency.
The state of emergency declared on April 10 by Gabonese president Ali Bongo will end on May 11. UPDATE: Beginning on May 11, Gabon ends the state of emergency instituted on April 10.
On October 7 the Gabonese government announced the Prolongation of State of Health Emergency for another 45 days until at least November 17.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On September 23, the Gabonese government announced that, flight restrictions have eased to allow three international flights per airline, per week. Land and sea borders are closed. All Gabon diplomatic missions abroad are prohibited from issuing entry visas to Gabon. Additional health/documents will be required upon arrival passengers must provide proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken within the last 14 days. Foreign nationals wishing to leave Gabon, need to obtain a letter of permission (“authorisation de sortie”) from the Gabonese Government and have proof of a negative corona virus test prior to departure.

description: On April 12, The Gabonese Government announced lock-down in the capital. Authorities announced the implementation of a 15-day lock down in the capital Libreville, and the nearby communes of Owendo, Akanda, Ntoum, and Pointe Denis as of Monday, April 13. As such, residents are only permitted to leave their homes for limited reasons, such as obtaining essential goods or seeking healthcare. Those working in industries deemed essential by the government are exempt from the measures.

description: On April 27, the Gabonese government announced companies should continue to encourage telework for employees but may gradually return to business and administrative activities. Work hours must be limited to 7:30 am to 2:00 pm. Health control devices such as thermoflash devices, hand sanitizer, and masks must be placed at company and administrative office entrances. - Small businesses such as hair salons, garages, tire repair ships, and artisan workshops may begin to reopen subject to social distancing measures such as reductions in the numbers of staff and clients, the presence of disinfectants, and the wearing of masks. - Other commercial enterprises such as hardware stores, building and construction entities, and retailers of office supplies, furniture, and appliances, will gradually reopen with social distancing measures in place."
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
